author: jfro
body:
## Steps to reproduce

```powershell
Import-Module Appx
```

## Expected behavior
Successfully imports & can run Add-AppxPackage etc. This worked in 7.0.3, but now forces me to switch to Windows Powershell for some scripts.

## Actual behavior

```none
Import-Module: Operation is not supported on this platform. (0x80131539)
```

## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19041
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: doctordns
comments.body:
The APPX module can be loaded like this:

```powershell
Import-Module -Name Appx -UseWIndowsPowershell
```

comments.author: doctordns
comments.body: and should the deny list be updated???

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body: This issue has been marked as duplicate and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.

comments.author: samus-a
comments.body:
PowerShell 7.2 (Windows 11):
```
PS > Import-Module -Name Appx -UseWIndowsPowershell
WARNING: Module Appx is loaded in Windows PowerShell using WinPSCompatSession remoting session; please note that all input and output of commands from this module will be deserialized objects. If you want to load this module into PowerShell please use 'Import-Module -SkipEditionCheck' syntax.
```

comments.author: doctordns
comments.body: @samus-a - that is the (currently) expected result. The impact is that all objects returned by the cmdlets in the module are serialised (and lose all their methods). And no object formatting XML is imported.

comments.author: samus-a
comments.body: @doctordns Ok thanks, so no reason to bother with the -SkipEditionCheck flag?

comments.author: doctordns
comments.body: Unless you really know what you are doing - no. This module is not compatible with .NET 6 but runs so I believe, using the compatibility mechanism. In theory, this module _should_ be loaded that way by default but isn't.

title: Appx module no longer imports in Powershell Core
